stimulusHtml:
"Quassatam ventis liceat subducere classem
 et silvis aptare trabes et stringere remos,
 si datur Italiam sociis et rege recepto
 tendere, ut Italiam laeti Latiumque petamus;
5sin absumpta salus, et te, pater optime Teucrum,
 pontus habet Libyae nec spes iam restat Iuli,
 at freta Sicaniae saltem sedesque paratas,
 unde huc advecti, regemque petamus Acesten."
 Talibus Ilioneus; cuncti simul ore fremebant
10Dardanidae.

Aeneid 1. 551-560

Answer the following questions in English unless the question specifically asks you to write out Latin words. Number your answer to each question

1. In lines 1-4 (Quassatam . . . petamus), (A) identify the three Latin verb forms that are dependent upon liceat (line 1) and (B) translate them in context.

2. (A) What is the case of laeti (line 4) and (B) to whom or what does it refer?

3. (A) Identify one and only one literary device found in line 5 (sin . . . Teucrum) and (B) write out the Latin word or words that illustrate it.

4. In lines 1-5 (Quassatam . . . Teucrum), which two Latin words can be translated “it is granted to strive for”?

5. In lines 3-7 (si . . . paratas), which five Latin words indicate the fear that Ascanius may not have survived?

6. In line 7 (at freta . . . paratas), which two Latin words are connected by the conjunction -que?

7. (A) Identify the place to which unde (line 8) refers and (B) the place to which huc (line 8) refers.

8. (A) Identify three perfect passive participles in this passage and (B) translate them in context.

9. (A) Identify the Greek character in Book 2 who also begs assistance from a king or queen and (B) briefly explain the circumstances. Answer in 1-2 complete sentences.
